The semantic [[wiki|wiki-site]] and [[database]] Enipedia lists energy systems data worldwide.<ref name="davis-2012"> {{cite thesis | first = Chris | last = Davis | title = Making sense of open data: from raw data to actionable insight | type = PhD | year = 2012 | publisher = Delft University of Technology | location = Delft, The Netherlands | url = http://enipedia.tudelft.nl/thesis/ChrisDavisPhD_MakingSenseOfOpenData.pdf | access-date = 2016-07-21 }} Chapter{{nbsp}}9 discusses in depth the initial development of Enipedia. </ref><ref name="enipedia-website"> {{cite web | first1 = Chris | last1 = Davis | first2 = Alfredas | last2 = Chmieliauskas | first3 = Gerard | last3 = Dijkema | first4 = Igor | last4 = Nikolic | title = Enipedia | publisher = Energy and Industry group, Faculty of Technology, Policy and Management, TU Delft | location = Delft, The Netherlands | url = http://enipedia.tudelft.nl | access-date = 2016-10-07 }}</ref> Enipedia is maintained by the [http://www.tbm.tudelft.nl/en/about-faculty/departments/engineering-systems-and-services/ei-section/ Energy and Industry Group], Faculty of Technology, Policy and Management, [[Delft University of Technology]], [[Delft]], the Netherlands. A key tenet of Enipedia is that data displayed on the wiki is not trapped within the wiki, but can be extracted via [[SPARQL]] queries and used to populate new tools. Any programming environment that can download content from a [[URL]] can be used to obtain data.<ref name="enipedia-architecture"> {{cite web | title = Enipedia:About — Architicture | url = http://enipedia.tudelft.nl/wiki/Enipedia:About#Architecture | access-date = 2016-07-21 }} </ref> Enipedia went live in March 2011, judging by traffic figures quoted by Davis.<ref name="davis-2012"/>{{rp|185}}{{nnbsp}}{{rp|at=fig 9.17}}
A 2010 study describes how community driven data collection, processing, curation, and sharing is revolutionizing the data needs of [[industrial ecology]] and energy system analysis.<ref name="davis-etal-2010"> {{cite journal | first1 = Chris | last1 = Davis | first2 = Igor | last2 = Nikolic | first3 = Gerard PJ | last3 = Dijkema | title = Industrial ecology 2.0 | date = October 2010 | journal = Journal of Industrial Ecology | volume = 14 | number = 5 | pages = 707–726, October 2010 [1] | doi = 10.1111/j.1530-9290.2010.00281.x | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1530-9290.2010.00281.x/full | access-date = 2016-07-21 }} </ref> A 2012 chapter introduces a [[system of systems engineering]] (SoSE) perspective and outlines how [[agent-based model]]s and crowdsourced data can contribute to the solving of [[global issue]]s.<ref name="chmieliauskas-etal-2012"> {{cite book | first1 = Alfredas | last1 = Chmieliauskas | first2 = Emile JL | last2 = Chappin | first3 = Chris | last3 = Davis | first4 = Igor | last4 = Nikolic | first5 = Gerard PJ | last5 = Dijkema | year = 2012 | chapter = Chapter 5 — New methods for analysis of systems-of-systems and policy: the power of systems theory, crowd sourcing and data management | editor-first1 = Adrian V | editor-last1 = Gheorghe | title = System of systems | publisher = InTech | location = Rijeka, Croatia | doi = 10.5772/28796 | isbn = 978-953-51-0101-7 | chapter-url = http://www.intechopen.com/books/system-of-systems/new-methods-for-analysis-of-systems-of-systems-and-policy-the-power-of-system-theory-crowd-sourcing- | access-date = 2016-07-21 }} </ref>

=== OpenEnergy Platform ===
{| class="infobox" style="width: 28em" |- ! style="width: 35%" | Project | style="width: 55%" | OpenEnergy Platform |- ! Host | {{plainlist| * [[Otto von Guericke University Magdeburg]] (IKS) * [[Fachhochschule Flensburg|Flensburg University of Applied Sciences]] * [[University of Flensburg]] * Next Energy – EWE Research Center for Energy Technology * [http://reiner-lemoine-institut.de/en/ Reiner Lemoine Institute] }} |- ! Status | active |- ! Scope/type | model-oriented |- ! Data license | dataset-specific |- ! Website | {{url|http://openenergyplatform.org/}} |}
The OpenEnergy Platform (OEP) is a collaborative versioned [[dataset]] repository for storing open energy system model datasets. A dataset is presumed to be in the form of a [[table (database)|database table]], together with [[metadata]]. Registered users can upload and download datasets manually using a web-interface or programmatically via an [[Application programming interface|API]] using [[Hypertext Transfer Protocol|HTTP]] [[POST (HTTP)|POST]] calls. Uploaded datasets are screened for integrity using deterministic rules and then subject to confirmation by a moderator. The use of versioning means that any prior state of the database can be accessed (as recommended in this 2012 paper).<ref name="decarolis-etal-2012"> {{cite journal | first1 = Joseph F | last1 = DeCarolis | first2 = Kevin | last2 = Hunter | first3 = Sarat | last3 = Sreepathi | year = 2012 | title = The case for repeatable analysis with energy economy optimization models | journal = Energy Economics | volume = 34 | issue = 6 | pages = 1845–1853 | doi = 10.1016/j.eneco.2012.07.004 | url = http://temoaproject.org/publications/DeCarolis_etal_2012.pdf | access-date = 2016-07-08 }} </ref> Hence, the repository is specifically designed to interoperate with energy system models. The [[Front and back ends|backend]] is a [[PostgreSQL]] [[object-relational database]] under [[Apache Subversion|subversion]] [[version control]]. Open source licenses are specific to each dataset. Unlike other database projects, users can download the current version (the public tables) of the entire [[PostgreSQL]] database or any previous version. Initial development is being lead by the Reiner Lemoine Institute, [[Berlin]], Germany. {{clear}}

The project website states that data might be subject to proprietary copyright, in which case the primary data owner should be consulted.<ref> {{cite web | title = Data – Open Power System Data | website = Open Power System Data | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://data.open-power-system-data.org | access-date = 2016-10-28 }}</ref><ref> {{cite web | title = Legal – Open Power System Data | website = Open Power System Data | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://open-power-system-data.org/legal | access-date = 2016-10-28 }} </ref> }} |}
The Open Power System Data (OPSD) project seeks to characterize the [[Germany|German]] and [[western Europe]]an [[Power station|power plant]] fleets, their associated [[Electric power transmission|transmission network]], and related information and to make that data available to energy modelers and analysts.<ref name="open-power-system-data"> {{cite web | title = Open power system data: a free and open data platform for power system modelling | website = Open Power System Data | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://open-power-system-data.org | access-date = 2016-10-28 }} </ref> The platform was originally implemented by the [[University of Flensburg]], [[German Institute for Economic Research|DIW Berlin]], the [[Technical University of Berlin]], and the energy economics consultancy Neon Neue Energieökonomik, all from Germany. The first phase of the project, from August 2015 to July 2017, was funded by the [[Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy]] (BMWi) for {{val|490000|p=€}}.<ref name="fischer-2015"> {{cite web | first = Kathrin | last = Fischer | title = Energiedaten für alle – Projekt "Open Power System Data" an der EUF gestartet | trans-title = Energy data for all — project "Open Power System Data" started at the EUF | language = German | date = 10 September 2015 | work = Informationsdienst Wissenschaft | location = Bayreuth, Germany | url = https://idw-online.de/de/news637284 | access-date = 2015-09-25 }}</ref><ref name="freist-2015"> {{cite web | first = Roland | last = Freist | title = Offene Plattform macht Energiedaten zugänglich | trans-title = Open platform makes energy data available | language = German | date = 14 September 2015 | work = Mittelstands Wiki | location = Bad Aibling, Germany | url = http://www.mittelstandswiki.de/2015/09/open-data-offene-plattform-macht-energiedaten-zugaenglich/ | access-date = 2015-09-25 }} </ref> The project later received funding for a second phase, from January 2018 to December 2020, with [[ETH Zurich]] replacing Flensburg University as a partner.<ref name="open-power-system-data-background"> {{cite web | title = Background and history – Open power system data | website = Open Power System Data | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://open-power-system-data.org/background | access-date = 2018-06-01 }} </ref>
Developers collate and harmonize data from a range of government, regulatory, and industry sources throughout Europe. The website and the metadata utilize English, whereas the original material can be in any one of [[Languages of European Union|24{{nbsp}}languages]]. Datasets follow the emerging [[Comma-separated values#OKI frictionless tabular data package|frictionless data package]] standard being developed by [[Open Knowledge International]] (OKI). The website was launched on 28{{nbsp}}October 2016. {{as of|2018|06}}, the project offers the following primary packages, for Germany and other European countries:
* details, including [[geolocation]], of conventional power plants and renewable energy power plants * aggregated generation capacity by technology and country * hourly [[time series]] covering electrical load, day-ahead electricity spot prices, and wind and solar resources * a script to filter and download [[NASA]] MERRA-2 satellite weather data{{efn|name=merra-2| MERRA-2 stands for Modern-Era Retrospective analysis for Research and Applications, Version 2. The [[Remote sensing|remote-sensed]] data is provided unencumbered by the [[NASA]] [[Goddard Space Flight Center]] research laboratory. }}<ref name="bosilovich-etal-2016"> {{cite book | first1 = Michael G | last1 = Bosilovich | first2 = Rob | last2 = Lucches | first3 = M | last3 = Suarez | title = MERRA-2: File specification — GMAO Office Note No. 9 (Version 1.1) | date = 12 March 2016 | publisher = Global Modeling and Assimilation Office (GMAO), Earth Sciences Division, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center | location = Greenbelt, Maryland, USA | url = https://gmao.gsfc.nasa.gov/pubs/docs/Bosilovich785.pdf | access-date = 2016-07-08 }} </ref>
In addition, the project hosts selected contributed packages:
* electricity demand and self-generation time series for representative south German households * simulated [[Photovoltaics|PV]] and wind generation [[capacity factor]] time series for Europe, generated by the [[#Renewables.ninja|Renewables.ninja]] project
To facilitate analysis, the data is aggregated into large structured files (in [[comma-separated values|CSV]] format) and loaded into data packages with standardized machine-readable metadata (in [[JSON]] format).<ref name="oki-data-package"> {{cite web | title = Data Packages | work = Open Knowledge International (OSI) | location = Cambridge, United Kingdom | url = http://specs.frictionlessdata.io/data-packages/ | access-date = 2016-10-31 }}</ref><ref name="oki-tabular-data-package"> {{cite web | title = Tabular Data Package | work = Open Knowledge International (OSI) | location = Cambridge, United Kingdom | url = http://specs.frictionlessdata.io/tabular-data-package/ | access-date = 2016-10-31 }} </ref> The same data is usually also provided as [[Office Open XML|XLSX]] ([[Microsoft Excel|Excel]]) and [[SQLite]] files. The datasets can be accessed in real-time using stable [[Uniform Resource Locator|URLs]]. The [[Python (programming language)|Python]] scripts deployed for data processing are available on [[GitHub]] and carry an [[MIT license]]. The licensing conditions for the data itself depends on the source and varies in terms of openness. Previous versions of the datasets and scripts can be recovered in order to track changes or replicate earlier studies. The project also engages with energy data providers, such as [[transmission system operator]]s (TSO) and [[European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity|ENTSO-E]], to encourage them to make their data available under [[Copyright#Free licences|open licenses]] (for instance, [[Creative Commons license|Creative Commons]] and [[Open Database License|ODbL]] licenses).<ref name="osi-2016"> {{cite web | title = Open Power System Data — An Interview with Lion Hirth and Ingmar Schlecht | date = c. 2016 | work = Open Knowledge International (OSI) | location = Cambridge, United Kingdom | url = http://frictionlessdata.io/case-studies/open-power-system-data/ | access-date = 2016-10-31 }} </ref>
A number of published electricity market modeling analyses are based on OPSD data.<ref name="schill-etal-2017-start-up"> {{cite journal | last = Schill | first = Wolf-Peter | last2 = Pahle | first2 = Michael | last3 = Gambardella | first3 = Christian | date = 3 April 2017 | title = Start-up costs of thermal power plants in markets with increasing shares of variable renewable generation | journal = Nature Energy | volume = 2 | issue = 6 | pages = 17050 | doi = 10.1038/nenergy.2017.50 | issn = 2058-7546 | bibcode = 2017NatEn...217050S}} </ref><ref name="schill-etal-2017-prosumage"> {{cite journal | last = Schill | first = Wolf-Peter | last2 = Zerrahn | first2 = Alexander | last3 = Kunz | first3 = Friedrich | date = 1 June 2017 | title = Prosumage of solar electricity: pros, cons, and the system perspective | journal = Economics of Energy & Environmental Policy | volume = 6 | issue = 1 | doi = 10.5547/2160-5890.6.1.wsch | issn = 2160-5882 }} </ref><ref name="kendziorski-etal"> {{cite journal | last = Kendziorski | first = Mario | last2 = Setje-Eilers | first2 = Mona | last3 = Kunz | first3 = Friedrich | date = June 2017 | title = Generation expansion planning under uncertainty: an application of stochastic methods to the German electricity system | journal = 2017 14th International Conference on the European Energy Market (EEM) | pages = 1–7 | doi = 10.1109/eem.2017.7981891 | isbn = 978-1-5090-5499-2 }} </ref><ref>{{cite arxiv|last=Zerrahn|first=Alexander|last2=Schill|first2=Wolf-Peter|last3=Kemfert|first3=Claudia|date=2018-02-19|title=On the economics of electrical storage for variable renewable energy sources|eprint=1802.07885 |class=physics.soc-ph}}</ref>
In 2017, the Open Power System Data project won the Schleswig-Holstein Open Science Award{{nnbsp}}<ref name="fischer-2017"> {{cite web | last1 = Fischer | first1 = Kathrin | title = Online-Plattform "Open Power System Data" erhält Preis für digitale Wissenschaft | trans-title = Online platform Open Power System Data receives prize for digital science | language = Germany | date = 26 January 2017 | work = idw — Informationsdienst Wissenshaft | location = Bayreuth, Germany | url = https://idw-online.de/de/news666992- | access-date = 2017-12-15 }} </ref> and the Germany Land of Ideas award.<ref name="deutschland-land-der-ideen-2017"> {{cite web | title = Open Power System Data (OPSD): open platform for energy data | date = 2017 | work = Deutschland Land der Ideen | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://land-der-ideen.de/en/project/open-power-system-data-opsd-open-platform-for-energy-data-13 | access-date = 2017-12-15 }} </ref>

=== OpenEI ===
{{main|OpenEI}}
{| class="infobox" style="width: 28em" |- ! style="width: 35%" | Project | style="width: 55%" | OpenEI |- ! Host | [[National Renewable Energy Laboratory]] |- ! Status | active |- ! Scope/type | US focus |- ! Data license | {{flatlist| * [[CC0]] * open licenses }} |- ! Website | {{url|http://en.openei.org}} |}
[[OpenEI|Open Energy Information]] (OpenEI) is a [[Computer-supported collaboration|collaborative]] [[website]], run by the US government, providing [[open data|open]] energy data to software developers, analysts, users, consumers, and policymakers.<ref name="openei-homepage"> {{cite web | title = OpenEI — Energy Information, Data, and other Resources | website = OpenEI | url = http://en.openei.org | access-date = 2016-09-26 }}</ref><ref name="brodt-giles-2012"> {{cite book | last = Brodt-Giles | first = Debbie | title = WREF 2012: OpenEI — an open energy data and information exchange for international audiences | date = 2012 | publisher = National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) | location = Golden, CO, USA | url = https://ases.conference-services.net/resources/252/2859/pdf/SOLAR2012_0677_full%20paper.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-24 }} </ref> The platform is sponsored by the [[United States Department of Energy]] (DOE) and is being developed by the [[National Renewable Energy Laboratory]] (NREL).<ref name="brodt-giles-2012"/> OpenEI launched on 9{{nbsp}}December 2009.<ref name="garvin-2009"> {{cite web | first = Peggy | last = Garvin | title = New Gateway: Open Energy Info | work = SLA Government Information Division | location = Dayton, OH, USA | access-date = 2016-09-26 | date = 12 December 2009 | url = http://govinfo.sla.org/2009/12/12/new-gateway-open-energy-info/ }} </ref> While much of its data is from US government sources, the platform is intended to be open and global in scope.
OpenEI provides two mechanisms for contributing structured information: a [[semantic wiki]] (using [[MediaWiki]] and the [[Semantic MediaWiki]] extension) for collaboratively-managed resources and a [[dataset]] upload facility for contributor-controlled resources. US government data is distributed under a [[CC0]] [[public domain]] dedication, whereas other contributors are free to select an open data license of their choice. Users can rate data using a five-star system, based on accessibility, adaptability, usefulness, and general quality.<ref name="brodt-giles-2012"/> Individual datasets can be manually downloaded in an appropriate format, often as [[Comma-separated values|CSV]] files.<ref name="brodt-giles-2012"/> [[Scripting language|Scripts]] for processing data can also be shared through the site. In order to build a community around the platform, a number of [[Internet forum|forums]] are offered covering energy system data and related topics.<ref name="openei-homepage"/>
Most of the data on OpenEI is exposed as [[Linked data#Linked open data|linked open data]] (LOD) (described [[#tag-linked-open-data|elsewhere]] on this page). OpenEI also uses LOD methods to populate its definitions throughout the wiki with real-time connections to [[DBPedia]], [[#reegle|reegle]], and [[Wikipedia]].<ref name="brodt-giles-2012"/><ref name="bauer-and-kaltenboeck-2012"> {{cite book | last1 = Bauer | first1 = Florian | last2 = Kaltenböck | first2 = Martin | title = Linked open data: the essentials: a quick start guide for decision makers | date = 2012 | publisher = edition mono/monochrom | location = Vienna, Austria | isbn = 978-3-902796-05-9 | url = https://www.semantic-web.at/LOD-TheEssentials.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-26 }} </ref>{{rp|46–49}}
OpenEI has been used to classify geothermal resources in the United States.<ref name="young-etal-2014"> {{cite book | last1 = Young | first1 = Katherine | last2 = Bennett | first2 = Mitchell | last3 = Atkins | first3 = Darren | title = Geothermal exploration case studies on OpenEI | date = 25 February 2014 | publisher = National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) | location = USA | url = http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy14osti/61437.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-24 }} </ref> And to publicize municipal utility rates, again within the US.<ref name="scanion-20"> {{cite web | first = Bill | last = Scanion | title = Nationwide Utility Rates Now on OpenEI | date = 7 September 2011 | website = Renewable Energy World | location = Nashua, NH, USA | url = http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/articles/2011/09/nationwide-utility-rates-now-on-open-ei.html | access-date = 2016-09-24 }} </ref>

=== OpenGridMap ===
{| class="infobox" style="width: 28em" |- ! style="width: 35%" | Project | style="width: 55%" | OpenGridMap |- ! Host | [[Technical University of Munich]] |- ! Status | active |- ! Scope/type | electricity grid data worldwide |- ! Code license | [[Proprietary software|proprietary copyright]] |- ! Data license | [[Creative Commons license|{{nowrap|CC BY 3.0 IGO}}]] preferred |- ! Website | {{url|http://opengridmap.com/}} |- ! Web application | URL TBA |- ! Repository | {{url|https://github.com/OpenGridMap}} |}
OpenGridMap employs [[crowdsourcing]] techniques to gather detailed data on electricity network components and then infer a realistic network structure using methods from [[Correlation and dependence|statistics]] and [[graph theory]]. The scope of the project is worldwide and both distribution and transmission networks can be [[Reverse engineering|reverse engineered]]. The project is managed by the Chair of Business Information Systems, [https://www.in.tum.de/en.html TUM Department of Informatics], [[Technical University of Munich]], [[Munich]], Germany. The project maintains a website and a [[Facebook]] page and provides an [[Android (operating system)|Android]] [[mobile app]] to help the public document electrical devices, such as [[transformer]]s and [[Electrical substation|substations]]. The bulk of the data is being made available under a [[Creative Commons license|Creative Commons]] {{nowrap|CC BY 3.0 IGO}} license.<ref name="opengridmap-terms-of-use"> {{cite web | title = OpenGridMap — Terms of use | work = Technical University of Munich | url = http://opengridmap.com/terms/ | access-date = 2017-04-11 }} Terms of use last amended 25{{nbsp}}November 2016. </ref>{{efn|The IGO variant is designed for use by international agencies.}} The processing software is written primarily in [[Python (programming language)|Python]] and [[MATLAB]] and is hosted on [[GitHub]].<ref name="rivera-etal-2015"><!--4th D-A-CH Conference, EI 2015, Karlsruhe, Germany, 12-13 November 2015 --> {{cite book|title=Energy Informatics: Lecture Notes in Computer Science|last1=Rivera|first1=José|last2=Goebel|first2=Christoph|last3=Sardari|first3=David|last4=Jacobsen|first4=Hans-Arno|date=2015|publisher=Springer International Publishing|isbn=978-3-319-25876-8|editor-last1=Gottwalt|editor-first1=S|volume=9424|location=Cham, Switzerland|pages=179–191|chapter=OpenGridMap: an open platform for inferring power grids with crowdsourced data|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-25876-8_15|editor-last2=König|editor-first2=L|editor-last3=Schmeck|editor-first3=H}} </ref><ref name="rivera-etal-2017"> {{cite journal | last1 = Rivera | first1 = José | last2 = Leimhofer | first2 = Johannes | last3 = Jacobsen | first3 = Hans-Arno | title = OpenGridMap: towards automatic power grid simulation model generation from crowdsourced data | date = March 2017 | journal = Computer Science — Research and Development | volume = 32 | issue = 1 | pages = 13–23 | doi = 10.1007/s00450-016-0317-4 | issn = 1865-2042 }} </ref>
OpenGridMap provides a tailored [[Geographic information system|GIS]] web application, layered on [[OpenStreetMap]], which contributors can use to upload and edit information directly. The same database automatically stores field recordings submitted by the mobile app. Subsequent classification by experts allows normal citizens to document and photograph electrical components and have them correctly identified. The project is experimenting with the use of hobby drones to obtain better information on associated facilities, such as [[Photovoltaics|photovoltaic]] installations. Transmission line data is also sourced from and shared with OpenStreetMap. Each component [[Row (database)|record]] is verified by a moderator.
Once sufficient data is available, the transnet software is run to produce a likely network, using [[Correlation and dependence|statistical correlation]], [[Voronoi diagram|Voronoi partitioning]], and [[minimum spanning tree]] (MST) algorithms. The resulting network can be exported in [[Comma-separated values|CSV]] (separate files for nodes and lines), [[XML]], and [[Common Information Model (electricity)|CIM]] formats. CIM models are well suited for translation into software-specific data formats for further analysis, including [[Power system simulation|power grid simulation]]. Transnet also displays [[descriptive statistics]] about the resulting network for visual confirmation.<ref name="rivera-etal-2017"/>{{rp|3–5}}
The project is motivated by the need to provide datasets for high-resolution energy system models, so that energy system transitions (like the German ''[[Energiewende]]'') can be better managed, both technically and policy-wise.<ref name="energate-messenger-2016"> {{cite news | title = Münchner Forscher erstellen Stromnetz-Weltkarte | trans-title = Munich researchers are creating a power grid world map | language = German | date = 5 December 2016 | work = energate messenger+ | location = Essen, Germany | url = http://www.energate-messenger.de/news/169851/muenchner-forscher-erstellen-stromnetz-weltkarte | access-date = 2017-04-06 }} </ref> The rapid expansion of [[Renewable energy|renewable generation]] and the anticipated uptake of [[electric vehicle]]s means that electricity system models must increasingly represent distribution and transmission networks in some detail.
{{as of|2017}}, OpenGridMap techniques have been used to estimate the low voltage network in the German city of [[Garching bei München|Garching]] and to estimate the high voltage grids in several other countries.

=== reegle ===
{{main|reegle}}
{| class="infobox" style="width: 28em" |- ! style="width: 35%" | Project | style="width: 55%" | reegle |- ! Host | {{plainlist| * [[Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Partnership|REEEP]] * [[REN21]] }} |- ! Status | active |- ! Scope/type | [[Sustainable energy|clean energy]] |- ! Data license | {{mdash}} |- ! Website | {{url|http://www.reegle.info}} |}
[[reegle]] is a [[sustainable energy|clean energy]] information [[Web portal|portal]] covering [[renewable energy]], [[efficient energy use|energy efficiency]], and [[Climate change mitigation|climate compatible]] development topics.<ref name="bauer-and-kaltenboeck-2012"/>{{rp|41}}<ref name="reegle-homepage"> {{cite web | title = Clean Energy Info Portal — reegle | location = Vienna, Austria | url = http://www.reegle.info | accessdate = 2016-09-27 }}</ref><ref name="bauer-etal-2011"><!-- see also: https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-642-22285-6_21 --> {{cite book|title=Environmental Software Systems|last1=Bauer|first1=Florian|last2=Recheis|first2=Denise|last3=Kaltenböck|first3=Martin|date=27 June 2011|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-3-642-22284-9|editor-last1=Hřebíček|editor-first1=Jiří|location=Berlin and Heidelberg, Germany|pages=189–194|chapter=data.reegle.info – A New Key Portal for Open Energy Data|accessdate=2016-09-27|editor-last2=Schimak|editor-first2=Gerald|editor-last3=Denzer|editor-first3=Ralf|chapterurl=https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1007%2F978-3-642-22285-6_21.pdf}} </ref> reegle was launched in 2006 by [[Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Partnership|REEEP]] and [[REN21]] with funding from the Dutch ([[Ministry of Housing, Spatial Planning and the Environment|VROM]]), German ([[Federal Ministry for Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety|BMU]]), and UK ([[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs|Defra]]) environment ministries.<ref name="reegle-partners"> {{cite web | title = Partners — reegle | url = http://www.reegle.info/instructions.20.htm | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080229001007/http://www.reegle.info/instructions.20.htm <!-- bot retrieved archive --> | archivedate = 2008-02-29 | access-date = 2016-09-29 }} </ref> Originally released as a specialized [[internet search engine]], reegle was relaunched in 2011 as an information portal.
reegle offers and utilizes [[linked data#linked open data|linked open data]] (LOD) (described [[#tag-linked-open-data|elsewhere]] on this page).<ref name="bauer-and-kaltenboeck-2012"/>{{rp|43–46}} Sources of data include [[United Nations|UN]] and [[World Bank]] databases, as well as dedicated partners around the world. reegle maintains a comprehensive structured [[glossary]] (driven by an LOD-compliant [[Thesaurus (information retrieval)|thesaurus]]) of energy and climate compatible development terms to assist with the tagging of datasets. The glossary also facilitates intelligent web searches.{{efn| Alternative interfaces to the glossary, provided by the Climate Tagger project, include a [http://www.climatetagger.net/climate-thesaurus/tree tree view] and an [http://www.climatetagger.net/glossary alphabetic view]. }}<ref name="bauer-etal-2011"/>{{rp|191,{{nnbsp}}193}}<ref name="reegle-glossary"> {{cite web | title = reegle glossary | work = reegle — clean energy information gateway | url = http://www.reegle.info/glossary | access-date = 2016-09-26 }}</ref><ref name="reeep-2015"> <!-- see also: www.climatetagger.net --> {{cite book | title = Turning data into knowledge | date = 2015 | publisher = REEEP | location = Vienna, Austria | url = http://www.climatetagger.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/Climate-Tagger-Brochure.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-26 }} </ref>
reegle offers country profiles which collate and display energy data on a per-country basis for most of the world.<ref name="reegle-country-profiles"> {{cite web | title = Country energy profiles — Clean Energy Info Portal — reegle | location = Vienna, Austria | url = http://www.reegle.info/countries | accessdate = 2016-09-27 }} </ref> These profiles are kept current automatically using LOD techniques.<ref name="bauer-etal-2011"/>{{rp|193–194}}

=== Renewables.ninja ===
{{main article|Renewables.ninja}}
{| class="infobox" style="width: 28em" |- ! style="width: 35%" | Project | style="width: 55%" | Renewables,ninja |- ! Host | {{plainlist| * [[ETH Zurich]] * [[Imperial College London]] }} |- ! Status | active |- ! Scope/type | worldwide hourly PV and wind |- ! Code license | [[BSD-new]] |- ! Data license | [[Creative Commons license|CC BY-NC 4.0]] |- ! Website | {{url|https://www.renewables.ninja/}} |- ! Repository | {{url|https://github.com/renewables-ninja}} |}
[[Renewables.ninja]] is a website that can calculate the hourly power output from [[photovoltaics|solar photovoltaic]] installations and [[wind farm]]s located anywhere in the world. The website is a joint project between the [https://www.usys.ethz.ch/en/ Department of Environmental Systems Science], [[ETH Zurich]], [[Zürich]], Switzerland and the [https://www.imperial.ac.uk/environmental-policy/ Centre for Environmental Policy], [[Imperial College London]], [[London]], United Kingdom. The website went live during September 2016. The resulting time series are provided under a Creative Commons {{nowrap|CC BY-NC 4.0}} license and the underlying power plant models are published using a [[BSD-new]] license. {{as of|2017|02}}, only the solar model, written in [[Python (programming language)|Python]], has been released.<ref name="renewables-ninja-website"> {{cite web | title = Renewables.ninja | url = https://www.renewables.ninja/ | access-date = 2017-02-02 }} </ref>
[[File:Renewables ninja photovoltaics and wind energy database screenshot showing simulated pv output.jpg|left|thumb|Screenshot showing simulated photovoltaic output for a site in northern Italy for the year 2014]]
The project relies on weather data derived from [[meteorological reanalysis]] models and weather [[Meteosat|satellite images]]. More specifically, it uses the 2016 MERRA-2 reanalysis dataset from [[NASA]]{{nnbsp}}{{efn|name=merra-2}} and satellite images from CM-SAF SARAH.<ref name="mueller-etal-2015"> {{cite book | last1 = Müller | first1 = Richard | last2 = Pfeifroth | first2 = Uwe | last3 = Träger-Chatterjee | first3 = Christine | last4 = Cremer | first4 = Roswitha | last5 = Trentmann | first5 = Jörg | last6 = Hollmann | first6 = Rainer | year = 2015 | title = Surface solar radiation data set: heliosat (SARAH) — Edition 1 | publisher = EUMETSAT Satellite Application Facility on Climate Monitoring (CM SAF) | location = Hessen, Germany | doi = 10.5676/EUM_SAF_CM/SARAH/V001 }} Contains datasets from 1983 to 2013. File size {{val|3.6|u=[[terabyte|TB]]}}. </ref> For locations in Europe, this weather data is further "corrected" by country so that it better fits with the output from known PV installations and windfarms. Two 2016 papers describe the methods used in detail in relation to Europe. The first covers the calculation of PV power.<ref name="pfenninger-and-staffel-2016"> {{cite journal | last1 = Pfenninger | first1 = Stefan | last2 = Staffell | first2 = Iain | title = Long-term patterns of European PV output using 30 years of validated hourly reanalysis and satellite data | date = 1 November 2016 | journal = Energy | volume = 114 | pages = 1251–1265 | doi = 10.1016/j.energy.2016.08.060 | issn = 0360-5442 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0360544216311744/pdfft?md5=f9da71fa45cfb92de38598104f571c3d&pid=1-s2.0-S0360544216311744-main.pdf | access-date = 2017-02-01 }} {{open access}} </ref> And the second covers the calculation of wind power.<ref name="staffell-and-pfenninger-2016"> {{cite journal | last1 = Staffell | first1 = Iain | last2 = Pfenninger | first2 = Stefan | title = Using bias-corrected reanalysis to simulate current and future wind power output | date = 1 November 2016 | journal = Energy | volume = 114 | pages = 1224–1239 | doi = 10.1016/j.energy.2016.08.068 | issn = 0360-5442 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0360544216311811/pdfft?md5=c3845d0421d5fc74e013d79ed6b1f0a1&pid=1-s2.0-S0360544216311811-main.pdf | access-date = 2017-02-01 }} {{open access}} </ref>
The website displays an interactive world map to aid the selection of a site. Users can then choose a plant type and enter some technical characteristics. {{as of|2017|02}}, only year 2014 data can be served, due to technical restrictions. The results are automatically plotted and are available for download in hourly [[comma separated values|CSV]] format with or without the associated weather information. The site offers an [[Application programming interface|API]] for programmatic dataset recovery using token-based authorization. Examples deploying [[cURL]] and [[Python (programming language)|Python]] are provided.
A number of studies have been undertaking using the power production datasets underpinning the website (these studies predate the launch of the website), with the bulk focusing on energy options for [[Great Britain]].<ref name="staffel-and-green-2014"> {{cite journal | last1 = Staffell | first1 = Iain | last2 = Green | first2 = Richard | date = June 2014 | title = How does wind farm performance decline with age? | journal = Renewable Energy | volume = 66 | pages = 775–786 | doi = 10.1016/j.renene.2013.10.041 | issn = 0960-1481 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0960148113005727/pdfft?md5=cbd16fefd3d2bd2a517b0e5a87ba6fe9&pid=1-s2.0-S0960148113005727-main.pdf | access-date = 2017-02-02 }} {{open access}} </ref><ref name="pfenninger-and-keirstead-2015"> {{cite journal | last1 = Pfenninger | first1 = Stefan | last2 = Keirstead | first2 = James | date = 15 August 2015 | title = Renewables, nuclear, or fossil fuels? === SMARD ===
{| class="infobox" style="width: 28em" |- ! style="width: 35%" | Project | style="width: 55%" | SMARD |- ! Host | German [[Federal Network Agency]] ([[:de:Bundesnetzagentur|BNetzA]]) |- ! Status | active |- ! Scope/type | German, Austrian, and Luxembourg (DE/AT/LU) electricity systems |- ! Data license | {{flatlist| * market data visuals and underlying time series are [[Creative Commons license|{{nowrap|CC BY 4.0}}]] }} |- ! Website | {{url|https://www.smard.de}} |- ! Language | [[English language|English]] and [[German language|German]] |}
[[File:German-electricity-production-mid-dec-2017-bnetza-smard-portal.png|thumb|left | upright=1.2 | Plot from the SMARD site showing electricity generation in Germany in mid-December 2017]]
The SMARD site (pronounced "smart") serves electricity market data from [[Germany]], [[Austria]], and [[Luxembourg]] and also provides visual information. The electricity market plots and their underlying [[time series]] are released under a permissive [[Creative Commons license|CC BY 4.0]] license.<ref name="bnetza-smard-tos"> {{cite web | author = BNetzA | title = Data use | date = 2017 | work = Bundesnetzagentur | location = Bonn, Germany | url = https://www.smard.de/blueprint/servlet/page/bnetza-en/datennutzung/5808 | access-date = 2018-01-22 }} Terms of use for the BNetzA SMARD data portal. </ref> The site itself was launched on 3{{nbsp}}July 2017 in German and an English translation followed shortly. The data portal is mandated under the German Energy Industry Act (''[[:de:Energiewirtschaftsgesetz|Energiewirtschaftsgesetz]]'' or ''EnWG'') section §111d, introduced as an amendment on 13{{nbsp}}October 2016. Four table formats are offered: [[Comma-separated values|CSV]], [[Microsoft Excel#File formats|XLS]], [[XML]], and [[Portable Document Format|PDF]]. The maximum sampling resolution is {{val|15|u=minute}}. Market data visuals or [[Plot (graphics)|plots]] can be downloaded in PDF, [[Scalable Vector Graphics|SVG]], [[Portable Network Graphics|PNG]], and [[JPEG|JPG]] formats. Representative output is shown in the thumbnail (on the left), in this case mid-winter dispatch over two days for the whole of Germany. The horizontal ordering by generation type is first split into [[renewable energy|renewable]] and conventional generation and then based on [[merit order|merit]].

The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to energy:
'''[[Energy]]''' – in [[physics]], this is an indirectly observed quantity often understood as the ability of a [[physical system]] to do [[Work (physics)|work]] on other physical systems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://faculty.clintoncc.suny.edu/faculty/michael.gregory/files/bio%20101/bio%20101%20lectures/chemistry/chemistr.htm |title=Retrieved on 2010-Dec-05 |publisher=Faculty.clintoncc.suny.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-12-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geo.cornell.edu/geology/classes/Chapters/Chapter02.pdf |title=Retrieved on 2010-Dec-05 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2010-12-12}}</ref> Since work is defined as a [[force]] acting through a distance (a length of space), energy is always equivalent to the ability to exert force (a pull or a push) against an object that is moving along a definite path of certain length.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
== Forms of energy ==
* [[Chemical energy]] – energy contained in molecules * [[Electrical energy]] – energy from electric fields * [[Gravitational energy]] – energy from gravitational fields * [[Ionization energy]] – [[Binding energy|energy that binds]] an electron to its atom or molecule * [[Kinetic energy]] – ({{math|≥0}}), energy of the motion of a body * [[Magnetic energy]] – energy from magnetic fields * [[Mechanical energy]] – The sum of (usually [[macroscopic]]) kinetic and potential energies * [[Mechanical wave]] – ({{math|≥0}}), a form of mechanical energy propagated by a material's oscillations * [[Nuclear binding energy]] – [[Binding energy|energy that binds]] [[nucleons]] to form the [[atomic nucleus]] * [[Potential energy]] – energy possessed by a body by virtue of its position relative to others, stresses within itself, electric charge, and other factors.<ref>{{cite book|author=Jain, Mahesh C.|chapter=Fundamental forces and laws: a brief review|title=Textbook Of Engineering Physics, Part 1|publisher=PHI Learning Pvt. Ltd.|isbn= 9788120338623 |page=10|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DqZlU3RJTywC&pg=PA10#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=McCall, Robert P.|chapter=Energy, Work and Metabolism|title=Physics of the Human Body|publisher=JHU Press|date=2010|isbn=978-0-8018-9455-8|page=74|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LSyC41h6CG8C&pg=PA74}}</ref> ** [[Elastic energy]] – energy of deformation of a material (or its container) exhibiting a restorative force ** [[Gravitational energy]] – potential energy associated with a gravitational field. ** [[Nuclear potential energy]] * [[Radiant energy]] – ({{math|≥0}}), energy of [[electromagnetic radiation]] including [[light]] * [[Intrinsic mass#Rest energy|Rest energy]] – ({{math|≥0}}) that [[E=mc²]] an object's [[Intrinsic mass|rest mass]] * [[Surface energy]] * [[Thermal energy]] – a [[microscopic]], disordered equivalent of mechanical energy ** [[Heat]] – an amount of [[Thermal energy#Differentiation from heat|thermal energy]] being [[energy transfer|transferred]] (in a given [[process (thermodynamic)|process]]) in the direction of decreasing temperature * [[Work (physics)]] – an amount of energy being [[energy transfer]] in a given [[Process (thermodynamic)]] due to displacement in the direction of an applied [[force]]
==Measurement==
===Units===
[[Units of energy]] * [[Barrel of oil equivalent]] (~6.1178632 × 10<sup>9</sup> J) * [[British thermal unit]] (~1055 J) * [[Calorie]] (~4.184 J) * [[Current solar income]] – the amount of solar energy that falls as sunlight * [[Electronvolt]] – (symbol: eV) is the amount of energy gained by a single unbound electron when it falls through an electrostatic potential difference of one volt. (~1.602 × 10<sup>−19</sup> J) * [[Planck energy]], 1.22 × 10<sup>28</sup> eV (1.96 × 10<sup>9 </sup>J) * [[Erg]] – (symbol: erg) unit of energy and mechanical work in the centimetre-gram-second (CGS) system of units (10<sup>−7</sup> J) * [[Foot-pound (energy)|Foot-pound]] – (symbol ft·lbf or ft·lbf) is an Imperial and U.S. customary unit of mechanical work, or energy, although in scientific fields one commonly uses the equivalent metric unit of the joule (J). There are approximately 1.356 J/(ft·lbf). * [[Joule]] – (symbol: J) also called newton meter, watt second, or coulomb volt * [[Therm]] – (symbol: thm) a non-SI unit of heat energy. It is approximately the heat equivalent of burning 100 cubic feet of natural gas. In the US gas industry it is defined as exactly 100,000 BTU<sub>59 °F</sub> or 105.4804 megajoules. * [[Kilowatt-hour]] – (symbol: kW·h) corresponds to one kilowatt (kW) of power being used over a period of one hour. * [[Ton of oil equivalent]] * TPE – Ton Petroleum Equivalent, 45.217 [[gigajoule|GJ]], see [[ton of oil equivalent]]
===Related units and concepts=== * [[Volt]] * [[Ampere]] * [[Coulomb]] * [[Enthalpy]] * [[EU energy label]] * [[Fill factor (solar cell)|Fill factor]] – defined as the ratio of the maximum power (Vmp x Jmp) divided by the short-circuit current (Isc) and open-circuit voltage (Voc) in light current density – voltage (J-V) characteristics of solar cells. * [[Gigaton]] – Metric Unit of mass, equal to 1,000,000,000 (1 billion) metric tons, 1,000,000,000,000 (1 trillion) kilograms ** Any of various units of energy, such as gigatons of TNT equivalent, gigatons of coal equivalent, gigatons petroleum equivalent. * [[Gray (unit)]] – (symbol: Gy), is the SI unit of energy for the absorbed dose of radiation. One gray is the absorption of one joule of radiation energy by one kilogram of matter. One gray equals 100 rad, an older unit. * [[Heat]] * [[Mass-energy equivalence]] – where mass has an energy equivalence, and energy has a mass equivalence * [[Megawatt]] * [[Net energy gain]] * [[Power factor]] – of an AC electric power system is defined as the ratio of the real power to the apparent power.

==Physics of energy== * [[Energy]] * [[Activation energy]], explains the differences in the speeds of various chemical reactions * [[Alternative energy indexes]] * [[Bioenergetics]] * [[Chemical energetics]] * [[Physical cosmology#Areas of study|Energy in physical cosmology]] * [[Earth science#Earth's interior|Energy in Earth science]] that is responsible for the macroscopic transformations on the planet Earth * [[Electricity]] * [[Exergy]] * [[Green energy]] * [[Orders of magnitude (energy)]], list describing various energy levels between 10<sup>−31</sup> [[joule]]s and 10<sup>70</sup> changes from one form to another. * [[Energy (signal processing)]], the inner product of a signal in the time domain * [[Spectral density|Energy density spectrum]], relating to the distribution of signal energy over frequencies. * [[Potential energy]], the form of energy that is due to position of an object * [[Kinetic energy]], the form of energy as a consequence of the motion of an object or its constituents * [[Mechanical energy]], the potential energy and kinetic energy present in the components of a mechanical system * [[Binding energy]], a concept explaining how the constituents of atoms or molecules are bound together * [[Bond energy]], a measure of the strength of a chemical bond * [[Nuclear potential energy|Nuclear energy]], energy that is the consequence of decomposition or combination of atomic nuclei * [[Osmotic power]], also salinity gradient power or blue energy, the energy available from the difference in the salt concentration between seawater and river water * [[Gibbs free energy]], a related concept in chemical thermodynamics that incorporates entropy considerations too * [[Helmholtz free energy]], a thermodynamic potential that measures the "useful" work obtainable from a closed thermodynamic system at a constant temperature, useful for studying explosive chemical reactions * [[Elastic energy]], which causes or is released by the elastic distortion of a solid or a fluid * [[Ionization energy]] (IE), the energy required to strip an atom of an electron * [[Interaction energy]], the contribution to the total energy that is a result of interaction between the objects being considered * [[Internal energy]] (abbreviated E or U), the total kinetic energy due to the motion of molecules (translational, rotational, vibrational) and the total potential energy associated with the vibrational and electric energy of atoms within molecules. * [[Negative energy]] * [[Energy conversion]], process of converting energy from one form to another * [[Dark energy]], used to explain some cosmological phenomena * [[Energy quality]], empirical experience of the characteristics of different energy forms as they flow and transform * [[Energy density]], amount of energy stored in a given system or region of space per unit volume, or per unit mass * [[Energy transfer|Energy flow]], flow of energy in an ecosystem through food chains * [[Energetics]], the scientific study of energy flows under transformation * [[Stress–energy tensor]], the density and flux of energy and momentum in space-time; the source of the gravitational field in general relativity * [[Food energy]], energy in food that is available * [[Primary energy]], energy contained in raw fuels and any other forms of energy received by a system as input to the system. * [[Radiant energy]], energy that is transported by waves * [[Rotational energy]], part of an object's total kinetic energy due to its rotation * [[Solar radiation]], radiant energy emitted by the sun, particularly electromagnetic energy * [[Tidal power]], also called tidal energy, is a form of hydropower that converts the energy of tides into useful forms of power - mainly electricity, [[dynamic tidal power]], [[tidal lagoon]]s, [[tidal barrage]]s * [[Wave power]] is the transport of [[energy]] by [[ocean surface waves]], and the capture of that energy to do useful work — for example, [[electricity generation]], [[water desalination]], or the pumping of water (into [[reservoirs]]). Machinery able to exploit wave power is generally known as a wave energy converter (WEC). * [[Wind energy]] is the kinetic energy of air in motion;[[Wind power]] is the conversion of wind energy into a useful form of energy, such as using wind turbines to make electricity, windmills for mechanical power, windpumps for water pumping or drainage, or sails to propel ships

{{good article}} [[File:The Desert Ultra - Sand Dunes.jpg|thumb|225px|Natural patterns form as wind blows sand in the dunes of the [[Namib Desert]]. The [[barchan|crescent shaped dunes]] and the [[capillary wave|ripples]] on their surfaces repeat wherever there are suitable conditions.]] [[File:Yemen Chameleon (cropped).jpg|thumb|225px|Patterns of the [[veiled chameleon]], ''Chamaeleo calyptratus'', provide [[camouflage]] and signal [[aposematism|mood]] as well as [[sexual selection|breeding condition]].]]
'''Patterns in nature''' are visible regularities of form found in the natural world. These [[patterns]] recur in different contexts and can sometimes be [[modelled mathematically]]. Natural patterns include [[symmetries]], [[trees]], [[spirals]], [[meanders]], [[wave]]s, [[foams]], [[tessellations]], [[fracture|cracks]] and stripes.{{sfn|Stevens|1974|page=3}} Early [[Greek philosophers]] studied pattern, with [[Plato]], [[Pythagoras]] and [[Empedocles]] attempting to explain order in nature. The modern understanding of visible patterns developed gradually over time.
In the 19th century, Belgian physicist [[Joseph Plateau]] examined [[soap film]]s, leading him to formulate the concept of a [[minimal surface]]. German biologist and artist [[Ernst Haeckel]] painted hundreds of [[Marine biology|marine organisms]] to emphasise their [[symmetry]]. Scottish biologist [[D'Arcy Thompson]] pioneered the study of growth patterns in both plants and animals, showing that simple equations could explain spiral growth. In the 20th century, British mathematician [[Alan Turing]] predicted mechanisms of [[morphogenesis]] which give rise to [[Turing patterns|patterns]] of spots and stripes. Hungarian biologist [[Aristid Lindenmayer]] and French American mathematician [[Benoît Mandelbrot]] showed how the mathematics of [[fractals]] could create plant growth patterns.
[[Mathematics]], [[physics]] and [[chemistry]] can explain patterns in nature at different levels. Patterns in living things are explained by the [[biology|biological]] processes of [[natural selection]] and [[sexual selection]]. Studies of [[pattern formation]] make use of [[computer models]] to simulate a wide range of patterns.
==History== [[File:Cycas circinalis male cone in Olomouc.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Fibonacci]] patterns occur widely in plant structures, including this cone of queen sago, ''[[Cycas circinalis]]'']]
Early Greek philosophers attempted to explain order in [[nature]], anticipating modern concepts. [[Plato]] (c. 427 – c. 347 BC) — looking only at his work on natural patterns — argued for the existence of [[universals (metaphysics)|universals]]. He considered these to consist of [[Theory of Forms|ideal forms]] ({{lang|grc|εἶδος}} ''eidos'': "form") of which physical objects are never more than imperfect copies. Thus, a flower may be roughly circular, but it is never a perfect mathematical circle.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/platonism/ | title=Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy | publisher=Stanford University | work=Platonism in Metaphysics | origyear=2004 | date=7 April 2009 | accessdate=4 May 2012 | author=Balaguer, Mark}}</ref> [[Pythagoras]] explained patterns in nature like the harmonies of music as arising from number, which he took to be the basic constituent of existence.<ref>The so-called Pythagoreans, who were the first to take up mathematics, not only advanced this subject, but saturated with it, they fancied that the principles of mathematics were the principles of all things. [[Aristotle]], ''Metaphysics 1–5 '', cc. 350 BC</ref> [[Empedocles]] to an extent anticipated [[Charles Darwin|Darwin]]'s evolutionary explanation for the structures of organisms.<ref>Aristotle reports Empedocles arguing that, "[w]herever, then, everything turned out as it would have if it were happening for a purpose, there the creatures survived, being accidentally compounded in a suitable way; but where this did not happen, the creatures perished." ''The Physics'', B8, 198b29 in Kirk, et al., 304).</ref>
In 1202, [[Fibonacci|Leonardo Fibonacci]] (c. 1170 – c. 1250) introduced the Fibonacci number sequence to the western world with his book ''[[Liber Abaci]]''.<ref>Singh, Parmanand. ''Acharya Hemachandra and the (so called) Fibonacci Numbers''. Math. Ed. Siwan, 20(1):28–30, 1986. {{issn|0047-6269}}</ref> Fibonacci gave an (unrealistic) biological example, on the growth in numbers of a theoretical [[rabbit]] population.<ref>{{cite web | last = Knott | first = Ron | title = Fibonacci's Rabbits | url=http://www.maths.surrey.ac.uk/hosted-sites/R.Knott/Fibonacci/fibnat.html#Rabbits | publisher =[[University of Surrey]] Faculty of Engineering and Physical Sciences}}</ref>
In 1658, the English physician and philosopher [[Sir Thomas Browne]] discussed "how Nature Geometrizeth" in ''[[The Garden of Cyrus]]'', citing [[Pythagorean numerology]] involving the number 5, and the [[Platonic form]] of the [[quincunx]] pattern. The discourse's central chapter features examples and observations of the [[quincunx]] in botany.<ref>{{cite book |author=Browne, Thomas |authorlink=Sir Thomas Browne |url=http://penelope.uchicago.edu/gardennoframes/garden3.html |title=How Nature Geometrizeth |work=[[The Garden of Cyrus]] |date=1658}}</ref>
In 1917, [[D'Arcy Wentworth Thompson]] (1860–1948) published his book ''[[On Growth and Form]]''. His description of [[phyllotaxis]] and the [[Fibonacci sequence]], the mathematical relationships in the spiral growth patterns of plants, is classic. He showed that simple equations could describe all the apparently complex spiral growth patterns of [[animal horn]]s and [[mollusc shell]]s.<ref>[http://www.darcythompson.org/about.html About D'Arcy]. D' Arcy 150. [[University of Dundee]] and the [[University of St Andrews]]. Retrieved 16 October 2012.</ref>
The Belgian physicist [[Joseph Plateau]] (1801–1883) formulated the [[Plateau's problem|mathematical problem]] of the existence of a [[minimal surface]] with a given boundary, which is now named after him. He studied soap films intensively, formulating [[Plateau's laws]] which describe the structures formed by films in foams.{{sfn|Stewart|2001|pages=108–109}}
The German psychologist [[Adolf Zeising]] (1810–1876) claimed that the [[golden ratio]] was expressed in the arrangement of plant parts, in the [[skeleton]]s of animals and the branching patterns of their veins and nerves, as well as in the geometry of [[crystal]]s.<ref>{{Cite book | title=Proportion | author=Padovan, Richard | authorlink=Richard Padovan | publisher=Taylor & Francis | date=1999 | isbn=978-0-419-22780-9 | pages=305–306 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=Vk_CQULdAssC&pg=PA306}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | journal=Nexus Network Journal | first=Richard | last=Padovan | authorlink=Richard Padovan | title=Proportion: Science, Philosophy, Architecture | volume=4 | pages=113–122 | doi=10.1007/s00004-001-0008-7 | date=2002 | issue=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | first=Adolf | last=Zeising | title=Neue Lehre van den Proportionen des meschlischen Körpers |date=1854 | page=preface | nopp=true}}</ref>
[[Ernst Haeckel]] (1834–1919) painted beautiful illustrations of marine organisms, in particular [[Radiolaria]], emphasising their [[symmetry]] to support his faux-[[Charles Darwin|Darwinian]] theories of evolution.{{sfn|Ball|2009|page=41}}
The American photographer [[Wilson Bentley]] (1865–1931) took the first micrograph of a [[snowflake]] in 1885.<ref>{{Cite book | title=Encyclopedia of Nineteenth-Century Photography | volume=1 | first=John | last=Hannavy | publisher=CRC Press | date=2007 | isbn=978-0-415-97235-2 | page=149 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=PJ8DHBay4_EC&pg=PA149&dq=wilson+bentley+january+15#v=onepage&q=wilson%20bentley%20january%2015&f=false}}</ref>
[[File:Drcy.svg|thumb|[[D'Arcy Thompson]] pioneered the study of growth and form in his 1917 book]] In 1952, [[Alan Turing]] (1912–1954), better known for his work on computing and [[codebreaking]], wrote ''[[The Chemical Basis of Morphogenesis]]'', an analysis of the mechanisms that would be needed to create patterns in living organisms, in the process called [[morphogenesis]].<ref name=Turing>{{Cite journal| last= Turing | first= A. M. | authorlink=Alan Turing | title = The Chemical Basis of Morphogenesis | journal=[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B]] | volume = 237 | pages = 37–72 | date = 1952 | doi=10.1098/rstb.1952.0012 | issue= 641| bibcode = 1952RSPTB.237...37T }}</ref> He predicted [[Chemical clock|oscillating]] [[chemical reaction]]s, in particular the [[Belousov–Zhabotinsky reaction]]. These activator-inhibitor mechanisms can, Turing suggested, generate patterns (dubbed "[[Turing pattern]]s") of stripes and spots in animals, and contribute to the spiral patterns seen in plant phyllotaxis.{{sfn|Ball|2009|pages=163, 247–250}}
In 1968, the Hungarian theoretical biologist [[Aristid Lindenmayer]] (1925–1989) developed the [[L-system]], a [[formal grammar]] which can be used to model [[plant development|plant growth patterns]] in the style of [[fractal]]s.<ref name=L>[[Rozenberg, Grzegorz]]; Salomaa, Arto. ''The Mathematical Theory of L Systems''. [[Academic Press]], New York, 1980. {{isbn|0-12-597140-0}}</ref> L-systems have an [[alphabet]] of symbols that can be combined using [[Formal grammar|production rules]] to build larger strings of symbols, and a mechanism for translating the generated strings into geometric structures. In 1975, after centuries of slow development of the mathematics of patterns by [[Gottfried Leibniz]], [[Georg Cantor]], [[Helge von Koch]], [[Wacław Sierpiński]] and others, [[Benoît Mandelbrot]] wrote a famous paper, ''[[How Long Is the Coast of Britain? Statistical Self-Similarity and Fractional Dimension]]'', crystallising mathematical thought into the concept of the [[fractal]].<ref name=Mandelbrot/>
==Causes== [[File:Aphids and live young under Sycamore leaf.JPG|thumb|left|upright|Composite patterns: [[aphids]] and newly born young in arraylike clusters on [[sycamore]] leaf, divided into [[polygon]]s by [[vein (botany)|veins]], which are avoided by the young aphids]]
Living things like [[orchid]]s, [[hummingbird]]s, and the [[Structural coloration|peacock's tail]] have abstract designs with a beauty of form, pattern and colour that artists struggle to match.<ref name=ForbesGuardian>Forbes, Peter. ''All that useless beauty''. The Guardian. Review: Non-fiction. 11 February 2012.</ref> The beauty that people perceive in nature has causes at different levels, notably in the mathematics that governs what patterns can physically form, and among living things in the effects of natural selection, that govern how patterns evolve.{{sfn|Stevens|1974|page=222}}
[[Mathematics]] seeks to discover and explain abstract patterns or regularities of all kinds.<ref name=Steen>[[Lynn Steen|Steen, L.A.]]. ''The Science of Patterns''. [[Science (journal)|Science]], 240: 611–616, 1998. [http://www.ascd.org/publications/curriculum-handbook/409/chapters/The-Future-of-Mathematics-Education.aspx Summary at ascd.org]</ref><ref name=Devlin>[[Keith Devlin|Devlin, Keith]]. ''Mathematics: The Science of Patterns: The Search for Order in Life, Mind and the Universe'' (Scientific American Paperback Library) 1996</ref> Visual patterns in nature find explanations in [[chaos theory]], fractals, logarithmic spirals, topology and other mathematical patterns. For example, [[L-system]]s form convincing models of different patterns of tree growth.<ref name=L/> [[File:Dragon trees.jpg|thumb|The growth patterns of certain trees resemble these [[L-system|Lindenmayer system]] fractals.]]
The laws of [[physics]] apply the abstractions of mathematics to the real world, often as if it were [[perfection#Physics and chemistry|perfect]]. For example, a [[crystal]] is perfect when it has no structural defects such as dislocations and is fully symmetric. Exact mathematical perfection can only approximate real objects.<ref name=Tatarkiewicz>[[Władysław Tatarkiewicz|Tatarkiewicz, Władysław]]. ''Perfection in the Sciences. II. Perfection in Physics and Chemistry'', Dialectics and Humanism, vol. VII, no. 2 (spring 1980), p. 139.</ref> Visible patterns in nature are governed by [[physical law]]s; for example, [[meander]]s can be explained using [[fluid dynamics]].
In [[biology]], [[natural selection]] can cause the development of patterns in living things for several reasons, including [[camouflage]],<ref name=DarwinCh4>[[Charles Darwin|Darwin, Charles]]. ''On the Origin of Species''. 1859, chapter 4.</ref> [[sexual selection]],<ref name=DarwinCh4/> and different kinds of signalling, including [[mimicry]]<ref name=Wickler>{{cite book |last=Wickler |first=Wolfgang |authorlink=Wolfgang Wickler |date=1968 |title=Mimicry in plants and animals |publisher=McGraw-Hill |location=New York }}</ref> and [[cleaning symbiosis]].<ref name=PoulinGrutter>Poulin, R.; Grutter, A.S. (1996) "[https://www.jstor.org/stable/1312929 Cleaning symbiosis: proximate and adaptive explanations]". ''Bioscience'' 46(7): 512–517. {{subscription required}}</ref> In plants, the shapes, colours, and patterns of [[insect pollination|insect-pollinated]] [[flowers]] like the [[Lilium|lily]] have evolved to attract insects such as [[European honey bee|bees]]. Radial patterns of colours and stripes, some visible only in ultraviolet light serve as [[nectar guides]] that can be seen at a distance.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://plantphys.info/plants_human/pollenadapt.shtml | title=Plant Physiology Information Website | publisher=Ross Koning | work=Pollination Adaptations | date=1994 | accessdate=May 2, 2012 | author=Koning, Ross}}</ref>
== Types of pattern ==
=== Symmetry ===
{{further|Symmetry in biology|Floral symmetry|Crystal symmetry}}
[[Symmetry]] is pervasive in living things. Animals mainly have bilateral or [[Reflection symmetry|mirror symmetry]], as do the leaves of plants and some flowers such as [[orchid]]s.{{sfn|Stewart|2001|pages=48–49}} Plants often have radial or [[rotational symmetry]], as do many flowers and some groups of animals such as [[sea anemone]]s. Fivefold symmetry is found in the [[echinoderms]], the group that includes [[starfish]], [[sea urchin]]s, and [[sea lilies]].{{sfn|Stewart|2001|pages=64–65}}
Among non-living things, [[snowflake]]s have striking [[dihedral symmetry|sixfold symmetry]]; each flake's structure forms a record of the varying conditions during its crystallization, with nearly the same pattern of growth on each of its six arms.{{sfn|Stewart|2001|page=52}} [[Crystal]]s in general have a variety of symmetries and [[crystal habit]]s; they can be cubic or octahedral, but true crystals cannot have fivefold symmetry (unlike [[quasicrystals]]).{{sfn|Stewart|2001|pages=82–84}} Rotational symmetry is found at different scales among non-living things, including the crown-shaped [[Splash (fluid mechanics)|splash]] pattern formed when a drop falls into a pond,{{sfn|Stewart|2001|page=60}} and both the [[spheroidal]] shape and rings of a [[planet]] like [[Saturn]].{{sfn|Stewart|2001|page=71}}
Symmetry has a variety of causes. Radial symmetry suits organisms like sea anemones whose adults do not move: food and threats may arrive from any direction. But animals that move in one direction necessarily have upper and lower sides, head and tail ends, and therefore a left and a right. The head becomes specialised with a mouth and sense organs ([[cephalisation]]), and the body becomes bilaterally symmetric (though internal organs need not be).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://biocongroup.eu/DA/Calendario_files/Bilateria.pdf | title=Animal Diversity | edition=Third | publisher=McGraw-Hill | work=Chapter 8: Acoelomate Bilateral Animals | date=2002 | accessdate=October 25, 2012 | author=Hickman, Cleveland P. | author2=Roberts, Larry S. | author3=Larson, Allan | pages=139}}</ref> More puzzling is the reason for the fivefold (pentaradiate) symmetry of the echinoderms. Early echinoderms were bilaterally symmetrical, as their larvae still are. Sumrall and Wray argue that the loss of the old symmetry had both developmental and ecological causes.<ref>{{cite journal | jstor=4500143 | title=Ontogeny in the fossil record: diversification of body plans and the evolution of "aberrant" symmetry in Paleozoic echinoderms | author=Sumrall, Colin D. | author2=Wray, Gregory A. | journal=Paleobiology |date=January 2007 | volume=33 | issue=1 | pages=149–163 |doi=10.1666/06053.1}} <!--http://www.psjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1666/06053.1--></ref>

===Trees, fractals ===
[[Fractal]]s are infinitely [[self-similarity|self-similar]], iterated mathematical constructs having [[fractal dimension]].<ref name="Mandelbrot">{{cite book|author=Mandelbrot, Benoît B. | title=The fractal geometry of nature| date=1983 |publisher=Macmillan}}</ref><ref name="Falconer">{{Cite book | last = Falconer | first = Kenneth | authorlink=Kenneth Falconer (mathematician) | title = Fractal Geometry: Mathematical Foundations and Applications | publisher = John Wiley | date = 2003}}</ref><ref name="patterns">{{Cite book | title=Fractals:The Patterns of Chaos | last=Briggs | first=John | authorlink= |date= 1992|publisher= Thames and Hudson |page=148 }}</ref> Infinite [[iteration]] is not possible in nature so all 'fractal' patterns are only approximate. For example, the leaves of [[fern]]s and [[umbellifer]]s (Apiaceae) are only self-similar (pinnate) to 2, 3 or 4 levels. Fern-like growth patterns occur in plants and in animals including [[bryozoa]], [[coral]]s, [[hydrozoa]] like the [[air fern]], ''Sertularia argentea'', and in non-living things, notably [[electrical discharge]]s. [[L-system|Lindenmayer system]] fractals can model different patterns of tree growth by varying a small number of parameters including branching angle, distance between nodes or branch points ([[Internode (botany)|internode]] length), and number of branches per branch point.<ref name=L/>
Fractal-like patterns occur widely in nature, in phenomena as diverse as clouds, [[river|river networks]], geologic [[fault line]]s, [[mountain]]s, [[coastline]]s,<ref name=Batty>{{cite journal | journal=New Scientist | date=1985-04-04 | title=Fractals – Geometry Between Dimensions | author=Batty, Michael | page=31 | volume=105 |issue=1450}}</ref> [[animal coloration]], [[snowflake|snow flakes]],<ref name="snowflake">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=aHux78oQbbkC&pg=PA25&dq=snowflake+fractals+book#v=onepage&q=snowflake%20fractals%20book&f=false | page=25 | author=Meyer, Yves | author2=Roques, Sylvie | title=Progress in wavelet analysis and applications: proceedings of the International Conference "Wavelets and Applications," Toulouse, France – June 1992 | date=1993 | publisher=Atlantica Séguier Frontières| isbn=9782863321300 }}</ref> [[crystal]]s,<ref name="crystal">{{cite book| page=78 | author=Carbone, Alessandra | author2=Gromov, Mikhael | author3=Prusinkiewicz, Przemyslaw | title=Pattern formation in biology, vision and dynamics | date=2000|publisher=World Scientific | isbn=9789810237929}}</ref> [[blood vessel]] branching,<ref>{{cite book |chapter=Fractal aspects of three-dimensional vascular constructive optimization| author=Hahn, Horst K.| author2=Georg, Manfred| author3=Peitgen, Heinz-Otto | editor=Losa, Gabriele A. | editor2=Nonnenmacher, Theo F.| title=Fractals in biology and medicine | date=2005 | publisher=Springer| pages=55–66}}</ref> [[actin cytoskeleton]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sadegh|first=Sanaz|date=2017|title=Plasma Membrane is Compartmentalized by a Self-Similar Cortical Actin Meshwork|url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevX.7.011031|journal=Physical Review X|volume=7|issue=1|doi=10.1103/PhysRevX.7.011031|pmc=5500227|pmid=28690919}}</ref> and [[wind wave|ocean waves]].<ref name="nature">{{cite book | pages=44–46 | title=Fractals and chaos: an illustrated course | author=Addison, Paul S. | date=1997 | publisher=CRC Press}}</ref>

=== Spirals === {{further|phyllotaxis}}
[[Spirals]] are common in plants and in some animals, notably [[molluscs]]. For example, in the [[nautilus]], a cephalopod mollusc, each [[Camera (cephalopod)|chamber]] of its shell is an approximate copy of the next one, scaled by a constant factor and arranged in a [[logarithmic spiral]].<ref>Maor, Eli. ''e: The Story of a Number''. Princeton University Press, 2009. Page 135.</ref> Given a modern understanding of fractals, a growth spiral can be seen as a special case of self-similarity.{{sfn|Ball|2009|pages=29–32}}
Plant spirals can be seen in [[phyllotaxis]], the arrangement of leaves on a stem, and in the arrangement ([[parastichy]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.math.smith.edu/phyllo/About/Lattices/SpiralLattices.html | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100526030701/http://www.math.smith.edu/phyllo/About/Lattices/SpiralLattices.html | dead-url=yes | archive-date=26 May 2010 | title=Spiral Lattices & Parastichy | publisher=Smith College | accessdate=24 September 2013 }}</ref>) of other parts as in [[compositae|composite]] [[flower|flower heads]] and [[seed|seed heads]] like the [[sunflower]] or [[fruit]] structures like the [[pineapple]]<ref name=Kappraff>{{cite journal | url=http://www.scipress.org/journals/forma/pdf/1904/19040335.pdf | title=Growth in Plants: A Study in Number | author=Kappraff, Jay | journal=Forma | date=2004 | volume=19 | pages=335–354}}</ref>{{rp|337}} and [[salak|snake fruit]], as well as in the pattern of scales in [[pine cones]], where multiple spirals run both clockwise and anticlockwise. These arrangements have explanations at different levels – mathematics, physics, chemistry, biology – each individually correct, but all necessary together.{{sfn|Ball|2009|page=13}} Phyllotaxis spirals can be generated mathematically from [[Fibonacci]] ratios: the Fibonacci sequence runs 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13... (each subsequent number being the sum of the two preceding ones). For example, when leaves alternate up a stem, one rotation of the spiral touches two leaves, so the pattern or ratio is 1/2. In [[hazel]] the ratio is 1/3; in [[apricot]] it is 2/5; in [[pear]] it is 3/8; in [[almond]] it is 5/13.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Introduction to geometry|first=H. S. M. |last=Coxeter|author-link =Harold Scott MacDonald Coxeter|publisher =Wiley|date=1961|pages=169}}</ref> In disc phyllotaxis as in the [[sunflower]] and [[Bellis perennis|daisy]], the florets are arranged in [[Fermat's spiral]] with Fibonacci numbering, at least when the flowerhead is mature so all the elements are the same size. Fibonacci ratios approximate the [[golden angle]], 137.508°, which governs the curvature of Fermat's spiral.<ref>{{cite book | last =Prusinkiewicz | first =Przemyslaw | authorlink =Przemyslaw Prusinkiewicz |author2=Lindenmayer, Aristid |authorlink2=Aristid Lindenmayer | title =The Algorithmic Beauty of Plants | publisher =Springer-Verlag | date =1990 | pages =101–107 | url =http://algorithmicbotany.org/papers/#webdocs | isbn = 978-0-387-97297-8 }}</ref>
From the point of view of physics, spirals are lowest-energy configurations<ref>{{cite journal |author=Levitov LS |title=Energetic Approach to Phyllotaxis |journal=Europhys. Lett. |volume=14 |issue=6 |pages=533–9 |date=15 March 1991 |doi= 10.1209/0295-5075/14/6/006 |url=http://www.iop.org/EJ/article/0295-5075/14/6/006/epl_14_6_006.pdf|bibcode = 1991EL.....14..533L }}{{subscription required}}</ref> which emerge spontaneously through [[self-organizing]] processes in [[dynamic system]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Douady, S |author2=Couder, Y. |title=Phyllotaxis as a physical self-organized growth process |journal=Physical Review Letters |volume=68 |issue=13 |pages=2098–2101 |date=March 1992 |pmid=10045303 |url=http://link.aps.org/abstract/PRL/v68/p2098 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.68.2098 |bibcode=1992PhRvL..68.2098D}}{{subscription required}}</ref> From the point of view of chemistry, a spiral can be generated by a reaction-diffusion process, involving both activation and inhibition. Phyllotaxis is controlled by [[protein]]s that manipulate the concentration of the plant hormone [[auxin]], which activates [[meristem]] growth, alongside other mechanisms to control the relative angle of buds around the stem.{{sfn|Ball|2009|pages=163, 249–250}} From a biological perspective, arranging leaves as far apart as possible in any given space is favoured by natural selection as it maximises access to resources, especially sunlight for [[photosynthesis]].<ref name=Kappraff/>

=== Chaos, flow, meanders ===
In mathematics, a [[dynamical system]] is chaotic if it is (highly) sensitive to initial conditions (the so-called "[[butterfly effect]]"<ref>{{cite journal |last=Lorenz|first=Edward N. |authorlink=Edward Norton Lorenz |title=Deterministic Nonperiodic Flow|journal=Journal of the Atmospheric Sciences |date=March 1963 |volume=20|issue=2 |pages=130–141|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/abs/10.1175/1520-0469%281963%29020%3C0130%3ADNF%3E2.0.CO%3B2 | doi=10.1175/1520-0469(1963)020<0130:DNF>2.0.CO;2| bibcode = 1963JAtS...20..130L}}</ref>), which requires the mathematical properties of [[topological mixing]] and [[dense set|dense]] [[periodic orbits]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Elaydi, Saber N. |title=Discrete Chaos |publisher=Chapman & Hall/CRC |date=1999 |page=117 }}</ref>
Alongside fractals, [[chaos theory]] ranks as an essentially universal influence on patterns in nature. There is a relationship between chaos and fractals—the ''[[strange attractors]]'' in chaotic systems have a [[fractal dimension]].<ref>Ruelle, David. ''Chance and Chaos''. Princeton University Press, 1991.</ref> Some [[cellular automata]], simple sets of mathematical rules that generate patterns, have chaotic behaviour, notably [[Stephen Wolfram]]'s [[Rule 30]].<ref>Wolfram, Stephen. ''[[A New Kind of Science]]''. Wolfram Media, 2002.</ref>
[[Vortex street]]s are zigzagging patterns of whirling [[Vortex|vortices]] created by the unsteady [[flow separation|separation of flow]] of a [[fluid]], most often air or water, over obstructing objects.<ref>von Kármán, Theodore. ''Aerodynamics''. McGraw-Hill (1963): {{isbn|978-0070676022}}. Dover (1994): {{isbn|978-0486434858}}.</ref> Smooth ([[Laminar flow|laminar]]) flow starts to break up when the size of the obstruction or the velocity of the flow become large enough compared to the [[viscosity]] of the fluid.
[[Meander]]s are sinuous bends in rivers or other channels, which form as a fluid, most often water, flows around bends. As soon as the path is slightly curved, the size and curvature of each loop increases as [[helical flow]] drags material like sand and gravel across the river to the inside of the bend. The outside of the loop is left clean and unprotected, so [[erosion]] accelerates, further increasing the meandering in a powerful [[positive feedback loop]].<ref>{{cite book | first=Jacques | last=Lewalle | title=Lecture Notes in Incompressible Fluid Dynamics: Phenomenology, Concepts and Analytical Tools | chapter=Flow Separation and Secondary Flow: Section 9.1 | url=http://www.ecs.syr.edu/faculty/lewalle/FluidDynamics/fluidsCh9.pdf | date=2006 | location=Syracuse, NY | publisher=Syracuse University | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929075022/http://www.ecs.syr.edu/faculty/lewalle/FluidDynamics/fluidsCh9.pdf | archivedate=2011-09-29 | df= }}.</ref>

===Waves, dunes ===
[[Wave]]s are disturbances that carry energy as they move. [[Mechanical wave]]s propagate through a medium – air or water, making it [[Oscillation|oscillate]] as they pass by.<ref>French, A.P. ''Vibrations and Waves''. Nelson Thornes, 1971.</ref> [[Wind wave]]s are sea [[surface wave]]s that create the characteristic chaotic pattern of any large body of water, though their statistical behaviour can be predicted with wind wave models.<ref>{{citation | first=H.L. | last=Tolman | contribution=Practical wind wave modeling | title=CBMS Conference Proceedings on Water Waves: Theory and Experiment | date=2008 | location=Howard University, USA, 13–18 May 2008 | publisher=World Scientific Publ. | url=http://polar.ncep.noaa.gov/mmab/papers/tn270/Howard_08.pdf | editor-first=M.F. | editor-last=Mahmood}}</ref> As waves in water or wind pass over sand, they create patterns of ripples. When winds blow over large bodies of sand, they create [[dune]]s, sometimes in extensive dune fields as in the [[Taklamakan]] desert. Dunes may form a range of patterns including crescents, very long straight lines, stars, domes, parabolas, and longitudinal or seif ('sword') shapes.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/gip/deserts/dunes/ | title=Types of Dunes | publisher=USGS | date=29 October 1997 | accessdate=May 2, 2012}}</ref>
[[Barchan]]s or crescent dunes are produced by wind acting on desert sand; the two horns of the crescent and the [[slip face]] point downwind. Sand blows over the upwind face, which stands at about 15 degrees from the horizontal, and falls onto the slip face, where it accumulates up to the [[angle of repose]] of the sand, which is about 35 degrees. When the slip face exceeds the angle of repose, the sand [[avalanche]]s, which is a [[nonlinear]] behaviour: the addition of many small amounts of sand causes nothing much to happen, but then the addition of a further small amount suddenly causes a large amount to avalanche.<ref>Strahler, A. & Archibold, O.W. ''Physical Geography: Science and Systems of the Human Environment''. John Wiley, 4th edition 2008. Page 442.</ref> Apart from this nonlinearity, barchans behave rather like [[soliton|solitary waves]].<ref>{{cite journal | author=Schwämmle, V. | author2=Herrman, H.J. | title=Solitary wave behaviour of sand dunes| journal=Nature | volume=426 | issue=Dec. 11 | date=2003 | pages=619–620 [https://dx.doi.org/10.1038/426619a Abstract] | doi=10.1038/426619a | pmid=14668849|bibcode = 2003Natur.426..619S }}{{subscription required}}</ref>
